newsitem.title: POLAND: HACHETTE GOES TO COURT OVER RUCH SALE - PAP.
newsitem.headline: HACHETTE GOES TO COURT OVER RUCH SALE - PAP.

text.p: French firm Hachette has asked a Warsaw court to rule whether its initial deal on buying press chain Ruch SA, signed in December with the treasury ministry but later annuled, is legally binding, PAP news agency said.

PAP said, without naming any sources, that Hachette and its Polish partners asked the court to declare the agreement binding. It also said the group wanted the court to order the ministry to meet its earlier pledge to sell the Hachette-led consortium the newsstand chain which controls 65 percent of Poland's press distribution market.
Hachette and the Warsaw provincial court officials were not available for comment while the French firm's Polish partners, a publishers' group, declined commment.
In March, the treasury ministry abandoned the initial agreement to sell a 75 percent stake in Ruch to the Hachette-led consortium and invited new bids for the company.

The ministry said it had put aside the deal with Hachette, which offered to pay $83 million for the Ruch stake, increase its capital by $45 million and then invest another $155 million, because a more attractive offer emerged.
Hachette said the ministry had treated it unfairly because it invited new bids for Ruch after the French-led group had unveiled terms of its offer and refused to bid in the new tender.
The ministry has said it shortlisted two bidders in the next tender, one of which is a Polish group led by Universal and including private television Polsat SA and soft drink producer Multico SA.
The group earlier said it was ready to pay $80 million for a 40-percent stake in Ruch and pledged to invest a total of $200 million in the company. -- Warsaw Newsroom +48 22 653 9700
